title: lodash/fp _.remove fails to remove item from array (and returns wrong result)
cloneDeepWith doesn't use customizer when recursing
Exclude non-enumerable symbol-key properties
body:
Following up from https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/fd4808147d762ba40299bc67b5ae3807f20d6145#commitcomment-19932280
I'd like to see the code for that. Loop over all of the retrieved symbol keys, examine with `getOwnPropertyDescriptor` and `splice` out if non-enumerable?

Perhaps in the future with [`Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors`](https://tc39.github.io/ecma262/#sec-object.getownpropertydescriptors)? I do not know what may be less performant and in which situations. But, perhaps it doesn't return symbol keys.

title: CreateListFromArrayLike called on non-object
body:
Hey @jdalton!
Lodash `4.17.2` broke the build of [yourchoice](https://github.com/actano/yourchoice/pull/46). Here is the [build log](https://travis-ci.org/actano/yourchoice/builds/176295227).

It says
```
  1) rangeTo - range selection change current range when selecting new range range select after deselection happened when deselecting the anchor with remove "before each" hook for "should return range using bottommost selected item as anchor":
     TypeError: CreateListFromArrayLike called on non-object
      at node_modules/lodash/fp/_baseConvert.js:88:12
      at l (node_modules/lodash/lodash.min.js:50:176)
      at r (node_modules/lodash/lodash.min.js:5:194)
      at u (node_modules/lodash/lodash.min.js:47:481)
      at src/operations.js:152:15
      at l (node_modules/lodash/lodash.min.js:50:176)
      at node_modules/lodash/lodash.min.js:49:159
      at Context.<anonymous> (test/range-to.unit.js:290:22)
```

I can reliably reproduce this with lodash `4.17.2` as opposed to `4.17.1` where this bug doesn't appear. Do you know what could cause this?

title: Question about kebabCase() with mixed strings & numbers
body:
I couldn't find any spec about kebab-case so I'm asking the question here directly.

Steps to reproduce:

```
var _ = require('lodash');
_.kebabCase('string1')
```

Expected: `string1` (maybe? - again… I couldn't find a spec)
Actual: `string-1`

I guess the question is: should `string` and `1` be considered as two separate words or not?

The npm package `kebab-case` (see https://www.npmjs.com/package/kebab-case) seems to consider `string` and `1` are part of a single word, and returns `string1`.

Here's a reduced test case:
https://runkit.com/58342f752aa75b00141c162a/58342f762aa75b00141c162b

title: global leaks if webpack uses AMD
body:
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/dist/lodash.core.js#L3815

webpack by default transpiles 

` if (typeof define == 'function' && typeof define.amd == 'object' && define.amd) {`

to:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7133601/20504993/3f38837c-afff-11e6-9f4b-73003bbfa920.png)

and exposes a global unless you specifically disable AMD.

title: chained _.map with _.property iteratee shorthand
body:
I had code that plucks an objects arrays in the `id` property

```js
_.map(objs, 'id')
```

and had to sort it first, so I changed it to

```js
_.sortBy(objs, 'position').map('id')
```

And lodash complained that `'id'` is not a function, wouldn't it be more consistent if the `_property` shorthand applies to chained functions too?

title: isEqual seems to ignore symbol key properties
body:
```js
_.isEqual({[Symbol()]: undefined}, {})
// true
```

Hints:
- https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1318933
- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/getOwnPropertySymbols

title: Removed '-pre' postfix from links to documentation line numbers
body: This is in reference to [Issue #2838](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/2838). All source code links were updated from "4.17.2-pre" to "4.17.2".

title: Links to documentation line numbers aren't resolving
body:
In the documentation file, the links that reference source code line numbers underneath method names have the postfix '-pre' appended to the version number part of the link: 

`https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.17.2-pre/lodash.js#L6876`

These links won't resolve and give a 404 error. However if you remove '-pre', the link works fine. I'm about to create a pull request for this and link to this issue, but wanted to document this here.

title: typescript typings for lodash-es
body:
Currently in order to use TypeScript with `lodash-es` its a problem since they are not available.

This would allow the TS users to simply download this package + typings from original source `@types/lodash` and they get typings out of the box for lodash-es.

*also I didn't change customOmitClone and such things, only isInteger and isHybrid stuff -- if the suggestion is ok, then should I consider a branch from 4.17.2 rather than master?

title: pick behaviour changed in 4.17
body:
If you try this simple program with Lodash 4.16.6 and 4.17.1 you'll get two very different results:

```
var _ = require('lodash');
_.pick({ 'abc:1.0': true }, 'abc:1.0');
```

With lodash 4.16.6

`{ 'abc:1.0': true }`

With lodash 4.17.1

`{ 'abc:1': [ true ] }`

title: forEach + spread behaviour changed in 4.17
How can I disabled the property paths of _.pick?
_.pick picks wrongly and messes up result when using deep path
_.clone does not clone objects with Symbol.toStringTag
body:
LoDash Version: 4.16.2.

```js
_.clone({
  prop: 'val',
  [Symbol.toStringTag]: "Foo"
})
```
**Expected:**
* A copy of the object

**Actual:**
* Produces a new plain object with no properties.

This is because `'[object Foo]'` is not in `cloneableTags`.
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/lodash.js#L2697

Not sure how related this is to #2705.

add index.js? (lodash-es)

title: yarn.lock
body:
Seems like we shouldn't have a `yarn.lock` file here, since yarn itself doesn't support it in library code.

Read more here: https://medium.com/@boennemann/avoid-yarn-for-packages-and-fully-enjoy-its-benefits-for-application-development-8bdd4deb33cf#.ioey0xwl1

lodash/fp doesn't have WithKey variants.

I expect there to exist:

```js
_.eachWithKey((k, v) => console.log(k, v), { k1: "v1", k2: "v2" });
// k1 v1
// k2 v2
```

and at least:
```js
mapWithKey
someWithKey

```

title: 4.17 introduces BC-break when calling omit() on objects containing Immutable structures
Performance regression in _.omit in 4.17.0
body:
When using `_.omit` on an object with large object properties, the performance drops. When profiling, I see that the time is mostly spent in `baseClone`. It seems `baseClone` calls itself recursively for all properties. Looks like a deep clone for no reason. Will investigate further.

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.17.0/lodash.js#L13481
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.17.0/lodash.js#L2721

Quick perf comparison:
https://jsperf.com/lodash-4-17-0-omit3

title: Breaking change in _.omitBy (v4.17.0)
Breaking change between 4.16.5 and 4.17.0
body:
Updating lodash makes tests fail in Sequelize.
https://github.com/sequelize/sequelize/pull/6849
https://travis-ci.org/sequelize/sequelize/jobs/175630416#L2244

I cannot find the exact cause, but somewhere our UUID attribute is not converted to a string correctly anymore. While debugging it seemed it was related to an object losing its prototype chain (was class instance before, is plain object now). Maybe there was a behavior change, for example in `_.clone`?

title: Lodash 4.17.0 _.pick breaks when there are dots in keys
body:
With lodash 4.16.6:

```
> _.pick({'foo.txt': 'foo', 'bar.txt': 'bar', 'baz.txt': 'baz'}, ['foo.txt', 'baz.txt'])
{ 'foo.txt': 'foo', 'baz.txt': 'baz' }
```

With lodash 4.17.0:

```
> _.pick({'foo.txt': 'foo', 'bar.txt': 'bar', 'baz.txt': 'baz'}, ['foo.txt', 'baz.txt'])
{ foo: { txt: 'foo' }, baz: { txt: 'baz' } }
```

title: Update optional-dev-dependency to the latest version 🚀
body:
## Version **2.0.0** of [optional-dev-dependency](https://github.com/bcoe/optional-dev-dependency) just got published.
Dependency optional-dev-dependency
Current Version 1.4.0
Type devDependency
The version **2.0.0** is **not covered** by your **current version range**. Without accepting this pull request your project will work just like it did before. There might be a bunch of new features, fixes and perf improvements that the maintainers worked on for you though. I recommend you look into these changes and try to get onto the latest version of optional-dev-dependency. Given that you have a decent test suite, a passing build is a strong indicator that you can take advantage of these changes by merging the proposed change into your project. Otherwise this branch is a great starting point for you to work on the update. ---
Commits

The new version differs by 3 commits .

  • 1599fb0 2.0.0
  • 415ba93 Merge pull request #17 from hildjj/republish
  • a100536 Republish v1.4.0 as 2.0.0.

See the full diff.

Not sure how things should work exactly? There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html) and of course you may always [ask my humans](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new).
--- Your [Greenkeeper](https://greenkeeper.io) Bot :palm_tree:

title: _.defaultsDeep incorrectly works with array values.
body:
When I apply `_.defaultsDeep` for objects which have properties represented as array I got strange behavior: 

```
_.defaultsDeep({config: ['a/b']}, {config: ['b/a', 'c/d']}) // {config: ["a/b", "c/d"]} 
```

I expect that `config` property value doesn't change because it already has value. Could somebody tell me why it's possible?

title: _.toLower and _.toLowerCase
body:
Hi,

I read about other "issues" with these 2 methods but I was wondering why they behave differently with accented characters?

For instance:
> _.toLower("Développement Web")  --> "d**é**veloppement web"
> _.lowerCase("Développement Web")  --> "d**e**veloppement web" 

**Edited**:
Actually, I think that `_.toLower( _.deburr( <string> ) )` is what I was looking for

title: flattenDeep => pass a string, get U
body:
I used flattenDeep like this:
```js
_.flattenDeep('some string')
```
when I meant to do
```js
_.flattenDeep(['some string']);
```
I would have expected lodash to barf on this.

But instead I got `'U'`
```
  => Suman uncaught exception => AssertionError:  => Suman implementation error => path should be absolute here => 'U'
    at /Users/Olegzandr/WebstormProjects/oresoftware/suman/lib/watching/add-watcher.js:32:7
```
seems pretty strange

now I realize it is picking up the `U` as in `Users/` in the filesytem path.

I guess it can work with strings, but maybe it's not supposed to?

title: Documentation minsinforms on breaking changes to API, e.g. _.find
body: There should be some indication of when a breaking change happens to the API of a particular command. (In fact a diff tools for easy upgrading to see which commands had breaking changes between two random versions would be helpful) An example of this is the _.find command. The documentation for version 4.16.6 shows that _.find has been available since v0.1.0. Whilst it may be true that the command has been available, it is not true to say that _.find API has been available since v0.1.0 in its current form. Here is a picture of the documentation for v.4.16.6 and below that one for v3.10.1, where the API has changed - what's more a breaking change.

title: _.isNative is tricked by bound functions
body:
Not a really big deal, but `_.isNative` returns true on functions that have been bound (at least in Chrome), since it overwrites the `toString` method on them:

```JavaScript

const func = function(){}

_.isNative(func) // false

const myBoundFunc = func.bind();

_.isNative(myBoundFunc) // true

func.toString() // "function (){}"

myBoundFunc.toString() // "function () { [native code] }"

```

title: When called multiple times, _.set creates different result based on the order of the calls
body:
Our object keys follows a pattern where they are a combination of numbers and underscores like
  1
  1_2
  1_44_3
etc.
Our object tree also includes arrays.

This code creates an array with an object inside
```js
let x = {}
_.set(x, "y[2].3_4", "value 2")
_.set(x, "y[2].5", "value 1")
```
This code creates an array with an array inside. 
```js
let x = {}
_.set(x, "y[2].5", "value 1")
_.set(x, "y[2].3_4", "value 2")
```
It is not possible to solve this issue by using setWith, since the customizer cannot see if bracket notation or dot notation was used.

title: fp.mergeAllWith ignores customizer when sources array has length > 2
body:
```javascript
var other = [{ 'a': 3, 'b': 4 }, {'a': 5 }];
fp.mergeAllWith(console.log.bind(console), other); // logs to the console

other = [{ 'a': 3, 'b': 4 }, {'a': 5, 'b': 2}, {'a':7, 'b': 12}];
fp.mergeAllWith(console.log.bind(console), other); // doesn't log to the console
```

It seems to be running the normal fp.mergeAll for the second case. Am I doing this wrong or is this a bug?

title: Including standalone utility functions cause drastic bundle size increase
body:
Example:

* Bundling `lodash/assign` adds 38.02 KB. `lodash/assign` can be implemented in a lot less code, e.g. https://github.com/sindresorhus/object-assign is just 1.94 KB.
* Bundling `lodash/filter` adds 83.09 KB.

"filter" function is a particularly convoluted example.

I have built a [dependency-tree](https://github.com/dependents/node-dependency-tree) for `./node_modules/lodash/filter.js`. It includes the following files 110 files.

```sh
$ dependency-tree --directory ./node_modules/lodash ./node_modules/lodash/filter.js --list-form | wc -l
110
```

In case of the "filter" function, there is no one single dependency that causes the bloat:

```
dependency-tree --directory ./node_modules/lodash ./node_modules/lodash/filter.js --list-form | xargs ls -lh
```

title: [fp] negate + curried functions
body:
Would it be possible for `negate` to support accepting curried functions? I would expect this:
`_.negate((n, m) => (n + m) % 2 === 0)(2)`
return curried function instead of running predicate right away

body: https://greenkeeper.io/

title: parseInt throws toString(string).replace is not a function
body:
If I call `parseInt()` with a number like `parseInt(123)` I get 

```
TypeError: toString(string).replace is not a function. (In 'toString(string).replace(reTrim, '')', 'toString(string).replace' is undefined)
```

It seems that `toString(string)` does not make a string for it:

```
> typeof toString(123)
< "number"
```

My code is running on iOS if that matters.

title: Ability to render "false" values as empty strings with _.template?

body: https://greenkeeper.io/

title: Update _.chunk to better leverage immutability and ES6 constructs
body:
This version of chunk does not require the `guard` parameter and better utilizes ES6 constructs to chunk arrays. I think this style is easier to reason with (and looks prettier 👍). 
However this does require ES6, so that is why I bumped the node engine up to >=v6.0.0. 

If you want to make a new branch for rewriting many of the functions in ES6/7, I can begin updating other functions as well.

title: Possible regression in xor in 4.16.5
body:
I've not yet been able to reproduce the error outside our own codebase, but with 4.16.5, xoring identical arrays will sometimes return `[undefined]`. Rolling back to 4.16.4 fixes the issue.

I have no idea what the exact combination of factors is. I'm still working on reproducing the issue. Will update this post once I know more.

There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html) and while I’m just a bot, there is a group of people who are happy to teach me new things. [Let them know](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new). Good luck with your project :sparkles: You rock! :palm_tree: --- [GitHub Release](https://github.com/Widdershin/markdown-doctest/releases/tag/v0.9.0)
  • Add simple usage text, available via markdown-doctest --help or markdown-doctest -h

title: Possible regression in 4.14.1? path ".[0]" has changed behaviour.
body:
4.14.0 seems to to discard the leading dot:

```
l.toPath('.[0]')
[ '0' ]
```

while in 4.14.1 (with c253e8d) the behaviour changed:

```
> l.toPath('.[0]')
[ '', '0' ]
```

is this intended (i'm not sure, i cannot find a spec for paths expressions in lodash)?

title: _.inRange() logic?
body:
Hi, thanks for a great lib but this is not very portable or logic behaviour?

**lodash**

``` js
_.inRange(0, 50, 50) // => false
```

**ruby**

``` ruby
(0..50).include? 50 # => true
```

title: [fp enhancement] converge
body:
Im curious if there is a possibility of adding a method like - http://ramdajs.com/docs/#converge . I find it really useful for complex data transformations, especially in pair with http://ramdajs.com/docs/#call .

Also lenses are a big topic for me, is there any plan of supporting such methods in the future?

In addition I would like to ask what are the plans for the fp port. Will it stay as just a port of regular lodash methods + some aliases? Will there be more methods added which satisfies fp style beside regular lodash? In general - whats on the roadmap?

Thanks for a great lib!

title: Documentation: Callback arguments in argument list?
body:
Was there ever any thought given to listing the arguments of a callback function in the argument list?  Currently they're just in the main documentation body.  I think it's one of the more likely things that a user would have to check the docs for, and having it in the arguments list would make it easier to find.  

Personally, I find if I haven't used the lodash docs in a while this will always catch me out.

title: Feature request: lodash/fp wrapper for the "new" operator
body:
To make composition of constructors easier I propose a new method, let's call it `_.make()`, for example.
It would accept a constructor and its argument and call the constructor with the `new` operator, so the following two lines would work equivalently:

``` js
const object = _.make(Constructor, argument);
const object = new Constructor(argument);
```

So instead of writing

``` js
_.compose((message) => new Error(message), translate)("some message")
```

we would write

``` js
_.compose(_.make(Error), translate)("some message")
```

Update: since Lodash supports only ECMAScript 5 and above, we can actually name the method `_.new()`.

title: trying to use lodash with angular2-seed
body:
Hi there,

the angular2-seed people, where I posted this before couldn't help me, so i try it here.

Building the app for production leads to

```
[21:57:21] Starting 'build.js.prod'...

/home/martin/Projects/lf/client/node_modules/lodash/lodash.js:479
      case 0: return func.call(thisArg);
                          ^
SyntaxError: Invalid or unexpected token
    at /home/martin/Projects/lf/client/node_modules/lodash/lodash.js:14740:16
    at apply (/home/martin/Projects/lf/client/node_modules/lodash/lodash.js:479:27)
    at /home/martin/Projects/lf/client/node_modules/lodash/lodash.js:15124:16
    at apply (/home/martin/Projects/lf/client/node_modules/lodash/lodash.js:481:27)
    at /home/martin/Projects/lf/client/node_modules/lodash/lodash.js:6499:16
    at template (/home/martin/Projects/lf/client/node_modules/lodash/lodash.js:14739:20)
    at DestroyableTransform._transform (/home/martin/Projects/lf/client/node_modules/gulp-template/index.js:20:14)
    at DestroyableTransform.Transform._read (/home/martin/Projects/lf/client/node_modules/through2/node_modules/readable-stream/lib/_stream_transform.js:159:10)
    at DestroyableTransform.Readable.read (/home/martin/Projects/lf/client/node_modules/through2/node_modules/readable-stream/lib/_stream_readable.js:357:10)
    at flow (/home/martin/Projects/lf/client/node_modules/through2/node_modules/readable-stream/lib/_stream_readable.js:727:26)
```

But using it with the development server there isn't any error.

Im using versions:

```
# cat package.json | grep lodash
    "@types/lodash": "^4.14.37",
    "lodash": "^4.16.4",
```

Maybe you can give me a hint, or is it a bug i lodash, this could be caught somehow I think.

Thanks,
Martin

title: Feature Request: _.divmod
each/forEach method broken if key 'length' exist in object
body:
Hi, 

today found some error with _.each / _.forEach method. 

If we have object with key 'length':

`
var dimensions = {
   'length': 5,
   'width': 3,
   'depth': 1
};
`

...method will iterate through 'length' value (in example it will each to 2).

![each_bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3917470/19600764/bb55a276-97a6-11e6-86dd-f2fef8dee14c.png)
